text: UPDATED: JAN 6, 2017 Bottle from Burien Liquor and Wine. Nice pour - deep amber with off white head. Nose has caramel, nuttiness, prickly alcohol heat and very mild fruity hop resins. Flavor is toffee with a light alcohol burn on the finish, very nice creamy malt texture makes this enjoyable. Finish has lingering alcohol and some bitterness. Very nice warmer, bold winter sipper in an unassuming package.

Pours a thin light tan head on a dark straw body.
Aroma is dark fruits and dark grains.
Taste is also dark fruit sweet, with plenty of malt and a bit of lemon bitterness.
Texture is thicker.
Draught at The Local, Bellingham, WA; 6.8% ABVHazy dark amber color. Caramel brew, moderately sweet, solid but with no other quality. Simplistic.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear ruby tinged amber. Soft citrus, a touch of malt, nutty with a hint of fruit. Medium bodied, fruity, soft malt, toast, sweetness, fruit. Slow bitterness on the finish.

12 oz bottle from Tavour. Maritime Pacific Jolly Roger Christmas Ale is cloudy red brown beer with a thin head of white bubbles. Nose is sweet molasses just a touch of hops and cereal. Taste is resinously sweet with notes of caramel, toffee, fruit and a bit of spice. Body is silky and medium to thick.

Poured from a bottle. Pours a cloudy brown with an orange hue. Smell starts with dark fruits, maybe some fig or dates, followed by a bit of vanilla and some smokiness. Flavors start with sweet malts, some honey, then drift in a smokier direction with nuttiness and some spice on the end. Feel is medium with a little carbonation. Overall a nice winter warmer, would be nice to have sitting next to a fire.

12 ounce bottle poured to wine glass around 50 F
Appearance: dedark amber to reddish brown, minimal lacing and head
Smell : aroma of molasses, toasted malt
Taste: balance bitterness
Feel: fizzy making it feel creamy but no follow through
Overall: very good beer for the price
Brown with a tan head. Toasted malt profile, light dark fruits, toffee, slightly woody. Thick, smooth body. Finish has light bitterness and a faint boozy heat. The alcohol is very well hidden. Solid.
One of the most moreish Xmas beers on the market. Can drink it till the 10% abv knocks me over.

14 ounce on tap at Sharps Roasthouse near Seatac. The aroma is a little metallic with light caramel and toffee hints. Mildly hazy amber body with a strong yellowish head present. Starts with just a sweet barrage of malts. I get a lot of caramel malts primarily with a little nuttiness behind. Fairly sweet throughout. Easy drinking, and alcohol is well hidden.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a beer can glass on 12.02.14.

A: Dark fruit, raisin, and cherry. Its sweet smelling.

A: Some fizz for a head. Opaque purple/dark red body.

T: Raisin and fig newton dominate. Cherry, allspice, a tiny bitter sting on the back end, and a slight woodiness are subtle.

P: Crisp with a bubbly finish. Its refreshing and surprisingly lighter than other winter warmers.

O: This has a mulled cider quality. The spices take the edge off the sweetness, so its balanced. This is a favorite.
Bottle from world beers. Ours a dark reddish brown. Almost no head. Scent is, caramel, alcohol. Taste is malty, molasses. Pretty good.
Enjoyed at Ivar's in Seattle. Nice, spiced flavors, little bitter aftertaste. Would buy a case to enjoy at home.

On tap at the Porterhouse, pours a clear amber with a small beige head. Aroma brings out christmas spices and light bready malt. Flavour brings out light Christmas spices, caramel, and bready malt. Well-balanced and cohesive. A nice Christmas ale.
Bottle courtesy of toffsbury. Aroma of fruit, mainly raisins and currants. Bitter spicy English ale. Dried fruit and caramel notes too. Nice strong Christmastime ale.

Bottle. Pours a hazy dark brown color with a moderate tan head on there. Nose is extremely malt heavy, with a lot of caramel, bread and yeast coming through. Taste is sweet with just a hint of harsh booziness to it. OK.
Pours Amber to copper with an off white head. Strange mix of spice and hops. Not great.

I think I remember this beer being a thing. Like it was special and sought after or at least awaited by the beer geek crowd. This beer and the brewery have seem to be forgotten at this point. I picked up the beer for $1.75 for a 12oz bottle, seems like a fair price. Poured into a Blvd tulip glass. Color is dark ruby with a small head. The beer is clear but the dark color makes it look thick. Bottom of the bottle is crystal clear. To call this an English Strong Ale is a stretch, this would just be an American Strong as far as I am concerned. Its got a good deal of sweetness with lots of English tea and wet caramel biscuit. The biscuit becomes a bit burnty in the flavor as well. Lots of hops around but thankfully the bitterness is low (I loath caramel and high bitterness). This would have been very fun a decade ago. Now, its a fun memory.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: "heres a pretty nice, dark, malty and well balanced winter ale. very light on the spices, nutty and slightly malt heavy - nice on a cold night. mahogony in color. 1st beer from this brewer is pretty nice."
12oz in Washington. Darker copper brown. Foamy. Big sweet malt.. Lots of juice, soft caramel. Some alc sweetness. Fig, grape juice. Good.

$2 for 12oz bottle @ Rocket Market in Spokane, WA
Poured to NB tulip.

A: Pours amber and thick. Little/no visible head or lacing despite hard pour.

S: Pine, copper and aluminum. This is horrid and not making me want to drink it.

F: Sweet, alcoholic, not much here. Lightly bitter, hint of crystal malt in background. Boring.

M: Slicks the tongue with fine, low carbonation.

D: This recipe should be tossed out of the lexicon for what is normally a great brewery.

Serving type: bottle

01-09-2011
Bottle from trade to glass. Dated 11/12. Nice brew. Aroma of toffee spices and more. Darker amber pour. Taste of toffee and some dark fruits
Clear darker amber no head. Aroma of citrus, nutmeg, strong malt. Strong malt flavor strong citrus hops spice. Creamy mouthfeel. Well balanced, but strong. Alcohol noticeable.

Uncharacteristic Xmas ale; few spice notes. Rather, this is a big bold English ale. Quite thick and malty. Maybe just a tad boozy. Solid B. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Thanks to 5000 for sending this bottle my way. 2010 vintage. Brown with a white head. The aroma is full of toffee and caramel with some pine notes. The flavor is a bit more complex. I get some pine notes, but there is also some brown sugar, caramel and vanilla. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

(22oz bottle)  Pours a hazy orange body with a small white head.  Aroma of caramel, toffee, and pine.  Flavor of caramel, fruity, honey, toffee, and light spices with moderate bitterness in the finish.

(22oz bomber) clearish medium orange/amber, fine tan bubbles. Nose of rich malt, caramel, mixed nicely with English hops, honey, really nice nose. Taste of caramel, English hops, honey, orange peel, nice finish, good beer.

Sample at the brewpub. This brew is a clear dark amber color with a medium off-white head that dissipates steadily to an outer ring. Strings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malt, caramel and fruit. Medium to full body with flavors of caramel malt, ripe fruit and a bit of vanilla. The finish is sweet with a bready malt aftertaste. Decent all around.

Lightly hazy, deep copper. The nose is a little fuddy, some pennies, graininess and a little heat. The booze is hidden quite well. It is very sweet with plenty of caramel and chalky apple fruitiness. Maybe some redcurrant too. Some heat, mild bitterness. Its a little sticky but very smooth otherwise.

Dark, muddy brown coloured body with a very thin tan oily head. Aroma of alcohol, roasted malt, pit fruits, cherries, raisins, caramel and a hint of nuts. Medium-bodied; Assertive roasted malt at first with a very good sweetness from raisins, pit fruits, plums, cherries, all with noticeable malt and nuts behind. Aftertaste showing a touch of spices with a little alcohol warmth, but definite sweetness to go around. Overall, a nice and relatively complex beer, full of good flavours - a step down from a Barley Wine, and this is a good thing. Definitely worth trying if you can find it! I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Pear Delicatessen in Seattle, Washington on 11-February-2013 for US$1.70 sampled at home in [the real] Washington on 26-February-2013.

12oz bottle from Total Wine 
Appearance: Pours cloudy brown with a big frothy beige head and lots of sticky lacing 
Aroma: Toasted malts, nutty, spices and some hot alcohols 
Taste: Toasted malts, caramel, nutty, spices and bitter citrus in the finish 
A nice winter beer, easy drinking.
Pours a nutty dark brown. Shades of amber. No head. Roasted and smoked malts come chocolate. Sweet brown sugar. Spices.

Bomber, 2010 vintage. Pours dark amber, small off white head. Aroma is crystallized caramel. Toffee, honey, a hint of citrus. Taste: muted sweetness, crisp and hop bitterness (but not overpowering). Caramel and alcohol. 
Palate: lively carbonation, full-bodied. Overall: this comes together nicely, though I think I prefer my Christmas sipping beer to have more sweetness and a less assertive hop bitterness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from trade with michaelinwa.  Pours a dark amber color with a small head that quickly fades.  Aromas are caramel, molasses, toffee, honey, and slight fruitiness, citrus fruit I think.  Taste is pretty good.  Moderate sweetness, slightly burnt sugar, caramel, and honey.  Would like some more bitterness or fresh hops to balance but I understand here since its supposed to be an english ale.  Thick body, somewhat chewy mouthfeel.  A solid Christmas ale.

12 oz bottle chilled. Pours a deep bronze color with one finger of frothy white head that slowly subsides to edge of glass. Fairly clear. Pronounced smells of alcohol with a subtle fruitiness. Orange perhaps. Heavy flavor of malty sweetness with medium bitterness. Toffee and an orange liqueor flavor with spiced hops. Has an almost wine flavor to it. Medium bodied with a nice texture and lively carbonation. Has a long lingering bitter finish. Strong alcohol warming effect.

Nice copper pour with a beige head. Smells of fennel and bourbon. Slightly sweet with flavors of honey and again bourbon. Moderately bitter; hops have a citrus flavor and are well balanced to the sweetness. Consistently one of my favorite winter beers.

Pours a reddish copper with small off-white head.  Aroma of caramel malts, bread, and spices.  Flavor is dominated by caramelly sweetness.  Pretty thick and heavy, like cough syrup.  The high alcohol content is very noticeable.  OK, but a bit strong for my tastes.

2010 22 oz bottle from the brewery. Pours dark reddish amber with thick white head. Aroma is aged oaky malts with faint floral sweetness. Taste is big malty body balanced with honey sweetness and bitter pine and grapefruit hop notes. Strong, aged winter beer. Not extreme, but well balanced.

Clear dark amber color with lasting ivory sheen. Glazed caramel, pit fruit, sweet spicy aromas. medium body, average carbonation. Nice spicy caramel, pit fruit, floral flavors with a peppery alcohol warmth to finish--good.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: From a growler, shared by a fellow customer at Payette Brewing in Boise, Idaho (thanks, unnamed friend!).  Delivers with a robust candied sugar kick in the pants, predominately a sweet caramel malt.  Dobblebockish and strong with a sugary burn to finish.  (#4684, 7/8/2012)

Pours a pretty ruby/amber. Toffee and caramel nose. If I never saw the bottle, Id swear it was a Fullers 1845 or Vintage Ale. Heavy on the malts and showing some sweetness, but balanced with some clean hoppy flavors. A touch of heat. 2010 vintage.
Favorite Maritime brew. As someone mentioned, 2011 was very decent; great balance for a winter ale.

12oz bottle from Elise.  Murky, dulled burgundy-brown-red.  Respectable steady off-white head.  Deep, thick malt tones, some dry resinous PNW hop action.  Woody, a touch of vanilla and dark fruit.  This is pretty much an English Barleywine.   A slow sipper all the way, quite sweet and heavy on the palate.  An excellent beer.
From tap. Pours hazy orange to brown with a small white head. Aroma is light fruity and toasted amber malty. Smooth caramelish and bitter. Lingering dark fruity and smooth hoppy finish.
Golden brown with a big lasting head. Nice strong yeast nose. Sweet alcohol taste, yeast and wood notes. Yummy.

Bottle back from Seattle. Pours dark brown. Aroma is spice anise molasses and a little bit of roasty aroma. Flavor is much the same wih a full bodied toffee and sweet character. Finish is pretty sweet and has bit of a chalky texture. Roasty bittersweet sort of finish as well.
Draught at Six Arms. Candy sweet. Tons of sugar. Malty. Ok overall. Nothing amazing.

Great painted bomber.  Mostly clear, tea-brown beer with a thin filmy head.  Earthy caramel aroma.  tannic, chalky, woody, some raisin.  Astringent, woody finish, sometimes sugary.  Slightly thin mouthfeel. Comes off as a west coast brown.  Thanks to Triock for hauling back from his latest Pacific Northwest adventures.

Outstanding balance for a holiday brew.  Many try to overkill with stoutness, maritime pacific though has figured out how to balance holiday cheer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Thanks Andre.
Ar: Sweet cereal graininess, with a light bit of earthy hops.
Ap: Copper, clear - small off-white head with medium retention.
T: Big toffee and caramel up front, quite sweet - alcohol comes in next, bit of vinous grape - medium-low bitterness - long caramel finish.
P: Medium-fully body with medium carbonation - moderately dry finish.
O: A burly winter warmer - seems to be made for a cold evening - alcohol and caramel really give it a comforting impression.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2012 From 12 oz bottle into tulip. 

Pours clear dark amber with a couple finger head.

Smell is spicy and fruity. 

Tastes medium, spicy, bitter, hoppy, very powerful. Its a winter warmer for sure. 

Revisit: on tap at Bottleworks Christmas in July.

Pours ruby red with a small off white head. Smell sweet, subtle fruity notes. Taste fruit and malt, spices. Coats the mouth. Good.

Great this year (2011). Amber  and clear with small slightly brown head. Carmel and malty, with hints of hoppy spices. Good alcohol taste that warms you quickly. Smells sweet like molasses. You taste this all the way to your stomach and its all good.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2012 Finally, a well brewed ale from Maritime. Pours a medium brown, light head, plenty of malty aroma. Flavor is mostly carmelized malt, with moderate and pleasing complexity, and a decent amount of hop bitterness. Very balanced yet not boring. Great palate, nice lingering finish. One of my favorite local winter ales.

Update on 11/2012: Bottle vintage 2011 (one year old). Much better after one year. Maybe 2012 batch is not as good, but the aged version has a nicer malt flavor that seems to have been uncovered compared to the 2012 version. Definitely one to age, and will be interesting to try it again at 2 years.

Bottle. Dark copper and amber colored in appearance with a half-inch of beige head. Smells like brown sugar, malt, orange spice and pine resin. The flavor begins with lots of toffee, bready malts and caramel upfront along with some orange liqueur, vanilla, spicy hops resin and grapefruit toward the end. Mouthfeel is creamy with moderate carbonation and a bready, citrus finish with a slight alcohol burn. Its a little boozy around the edges but it definitely warms you up.

12oz bottle: Pours a clear deep copper bronze with a thin ring of white head.  Has a lightly sweet toasty caramel nose with some oxidation and light fruity notes.  Starts with good fullness and sweet toasty caramel malts with some English hop bitterness before a drier doughy bittersweet finish.  Pretty true to style, but could use a little more complexity.

Bottle.  Clear amber pour with a white head.  Sweet caramel malt aromas.  The flavor is sweet with all kinds of caramel malt and dark fruit flavors.  This bottle might be past its prime because there is a bitter medicine aftertaste that is very off putting..

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of malt, light diacetyl, and some caramel.  Poured deep amber in color with a small, creamy, dense, off-white/beige head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of small particles throughout.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is light to medium sweet and slightly bitter.  Tastes of malt, resin, light wood, light caramel, slight hops, and slight honey.  Medium body.  Viscous, creamy, smooth texture.  Average carbonation.  Lightly sweet, slightly bitter, malt, caramel, resin, light wood, slight hop finish is a little sticky and dry.  9%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

355mL thanks to CaptainCougar. The pour is a hazy reddish amber with a healthy yellow head. Nice lacework. Nose is sweet cherry, cheesy hops, sweet strawberry. Taste is cheesy hops, sticky specialty malt, small iron/metallic. Chalk and powder palate.

12oz bottle, thanks CaptainCougar.  Small beige head, hazy dark amber body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, some alcohol.  Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, alcohol, light vinous.  Medium-full body, some stickiness.

Bottle shared by CaptainCougar.  Pours clear to lightly hazy amber with a light, fizzy off-white head, short retention with no lacing.  Aroma is heavy sweet malt (caramel, bread, cookie), medium alcohol with brown sugar notes, light fruitiness with oak notes.  Flavor is moderate malt and sugar with dark fruits and bourbon with light spicy hops.  Full body and warmth, medium carbonation.
Bottle courtesy of CaptainCougar, thanks. Hazy amber copper color, small white head. Aroma of plums, raisins, cherry.  Taste has mixed summer fruits, lemon, sourness toward the finish. Not bad.

Bottle from hbmason...thanks Tim! - Pours a rosy brown, slightly hazy with a small fine-bubbled off-white head. Smells of light piney hops and smooth biscuity malt, herbal and a bit chocolately. Light spice. Grassy hops to begin, light caramel sweetness, bready malt. Piney on the finish, with chocolate and dark bready malt. Kind of an off finish. A little too carbonated, but fairly smooth otherwise.
shared by hbmason Thanks Tim12oz bottle-pours an off white head with copper color.  Aroma is pine, 2nd medium malt.  Taste is pine/herbal hops with some bite, 2nd medium malt-cocoa.  OK carbonation.
Draft pours hazy amber with a thick beige head. Aroma of mild spice and caramel. taste is sweet, lots of toffee, some floral hop and a mild bitter finish.

12 oz. bottle shared by dbsdelight at The Royale on the Tuesday Night Beer Showcase- thanks, Dan!  I had never heard of this brewery before.  Pours a clear red-orange-amber color with a small off-white head.  Aroma of plastic, spices, vegetal notes, mixed sweet fruits, and sweet malts.  Flavor of sweet malts, dried mixed fuits, caramel, and booze.  Medium-bodied, with high carbonation and a boozy, malty mouthfeel.  Not really my thing.

Shipped to me by my wife on a trip to Portland. Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a dark brown color iwth a medium sized tan head that left good lacing. The aroma was harsh fruity and floral hops with a sour caramel undertone. The flavor was tangy sour caramel with a light fruity hop presence though a bit rough. The finish was long with lingering sour caramel and rough fruity hops. Thick and full body. Interesting.
12oz bottle.  Nothing like I was expecting.  Pours a mostly clear copper color with a creamy beige head, nice lacing.  Very weak nose of grassy hops and faint dried fruits.  Acidic on the palate.
Excellent color and taste. First day of christmas accomplished! Very nice start to evening

Shared an 05 and 07 with my pretty friend beardface. Kind of orange pour with tiny head. Aroma is light generic hop and caramel, flavor is pretty much unfermented wort, One was sweeter, the other more bitter both were not that great. Interesting when at the end I poured both together they were much better.

12 oz. bottle from a local QFC. Nice thin head sitting on top. Hazy dark copper-colored brew. Subtle toffee and butter notes; also Im getting a little caramel as well. Nothing special about the aroma; its rather plain, if you ask me. Slightly bitter. Sugar, caramel, and butter dominate the flavor. This is quite bitter, considering most of the English Strong Ales that I have dont seem to be utterly bitter. Great use of hops meld with the aforementioned flavors. This beer has somewhat of an oily texture.

Bottled.  Dark red brown pour with a thick white head on it.  Has a rich malt aroma, caramely and a touch toasty.  Has a big malty flavor as well with a body of middling richness on it.  Sweet toffee, a little dried fruit, and toast are accompanied by light spiciness and a bitter hop finish that brings an elegant balance to this brew.

12 oz. bottle via trade with highibus - Pours a clear deep mahogany color with a medium size light tan head.  Nice lacing.  Flavor and aroma is toasted malt, spice, and herbal hops.  Medium body.  A nice beer.  Thanks Tom.

Definitely a barley wine. And a pretty good one, at that. Pours a dark brownish amber with a very dense off-white head. Malt-heavy - almost brings to mind cotton candy its so sweet - but the flavor brings it back a bit, both with hops and with alcohol. Big flavor, and a thick brew that lingers for a while - another good one from the folks in Ballard.
bottle, and tap at college inn moderate bitterness with a good palate. Slightly malty.

12 oz. bottle. Burnt caramel on nose with a trace of booze. Big malt, big hops and big, bold flavor. Hops win over in the end and it finishes with a sharp bitter bite that I think is a bit too strong. Alcohol is also a bit too prevalent. I still like the beer, but it seems like it could be a bit more balanced.
Malty/burnt caramel aroma accompanied by a clear red body and off white head. Good taste but nothing extraordinary. Finish is malty and lingering.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours dark amber with a thin off white head. This is very much a barleywine. Very thick and chewey in body. Im not sure what makes this a Christmas ale, but it sure tastes good. Lots of syrupy butterscotch flavors. Very nice.
2009 12. oz bottle.  poured a brown color.  light head.  nutty taste, but extremely smooth for the alcohol.  much smoother than past years.  this is a seattle favorite and for good reason.

Pours a super nice chestnet red with thin off white head. Gentle but nice aroma of berries and light alcohol. Nicely subdued but complex at the fame time. Carmel and dark fruit notes with only light sweetness. A hop presence reminicent of the PAC NW. Really hides the 9 percent well. Finish is hops and a light sweetness. More carmel, just really nice.

Its not Christmas in Seattle without this beer, and it was released late this year...Pours claret with beige lace.  Aromas of brown sugar and fresh citrus. Sugar, spice and red fruits in the taste.  Smooth with a creamy mouthfeel.

Maritime Pacific Brewing Company	"Jolly Roger Christmas Ale--""Yo-Ho-Ho!"&qu Release--12 oz. Bottle.  8.50% ABV	IBUs?	4.85 / 5.0.  Winter Ale.  Lacy off white mild head.Clear pretty bright rich ruby color.Toasted floral malt fruit wheat ester aromatic hop front.Rich smooth cloying sweet clean mild fruit doughy malty toasted caramel body.Rich hop spice EtOH dry hot  balanced dangerous smooth end.  WoW!  New Location Opened 12/2009.  Late Release.  12/28/2009	6-Pack--$9.99

12 OZ. bottle...Nice darl rich rby-colored body with a tan head, medium layerd body thats slightly creamy-though it runs fast, coffee-ish bite with a smooth sweet,hoppy, mallty finish. My personal "all-time" favorite beer.

12 oz. bottle from riversideAK.  Pours a clear copper color with a small off white head.  The aroma was moderaely sweet ripe fruits, caramel/ toffee, with some spices.  The flavor has some sweetness, although not as much as the nose indicated.  Caramel malt, dark fruit, apricot, earthy hops create bitterness.  This is medium bodied and smooth drinking.

Bottle...  Poured a hazy amber/ruby color with a beige head.  Musty aroma of spices, brown sugars, and malts.  A little boozy but the sweet malts balanced nicely with dark fruit flavors, toffee, caramel and earthy hops.

Bottle. Vintage 2005. Pours an amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty piney hoppy aroma with some hints of caramel. Sweetish malty chocolate and caramel flavor with some hoppy bitter hints. Has a warming malty spicy chocolate and caramel finish with some hoppy hints in the aftertaste.
Bottle. Pours Copper/amber, with an off white head. Aroma is caramel, malt, and toffee. Flavor is caramel, alcohol, and malt.

Brilliant red-amber body with a crisp head that fades. Cotton candy aroma with an intense bubble gum quality and gorgeous malt touch--one of the vey best english strong ale bouquets. The flavor is of refined candy malt and alcohol--transfixed so it does not waver--extremely consistent throughout and well balanced with  hop tone. A great english strong ale.
12 oz bottle pours medium copper brown with a slight tannish head.  Bready nose with some smoke and toffee.  Slight burnt coffee body.  A bit dry and some sweetness with the medium body.

Bottle shared by alexsdad.

Poured clear brown color with medium off-white fizzy head that mostly with good lacing. Medium roasted malt aroma with a hoppy tone. Medium to full body with a smoth texture. Medium to heavy flavor of roasted malt with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. 

Good interesting solid brew.

On tap at jolly roger tap room on valentines day. Cupid was good to us with this sweet, hoppy, roasted beer. Beautiful dark amber color, well-balanced beer with delightful hop finish. My favorite Christmas beer of the 2008 season.
smells and looks like a delicious winter ale. red and full. tastes way too sweet with a nice little hint of cloves. can definitely taste the booze in this one.  no real trace of hops in this one.
2007. Bottleworks. Scents of honey and vanilla; pours a clear amber but thick on the tongue.

Gift from Nathan.  Shared with Grant and Nathan on the evening of Republic Tigers.  Pours a darkish amber with a swirlly hue of brown.    Aroma is very spicy - so is the flavor.  Cinnamon and Clove and booooze dominate.  Thanks Chef Holm.

From the bottle pours dark copper with a soft off-white head. Big boozy nose, caramel, brown sugar, and soft citrus hops. The flavor was dominated by booziness, vodka burn and flavor. Im not sure what was going on, but this was one of the hottest beers ive had. Ill have to try again next year to see if its different.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2009 On tap at Georgetown Liquor Company.  Pours a reddish brown with a good-sized head.  Aroma was not very strong- a little roasty and malty.  Flavor was similarly malty, with a little bit of spice and a hoppy finish.  I didnt know the ABV was so high when I ordered it, but I figured it out, as I could definitely taste the alcohol every once and a while (it wasnt unpleasant or overpowering though).

Shaker pint draft at the brewpub.  Pour is ruby golden with a small tan head.  Aroma of sweet caramel malt, dark fruit and some bitter hoppiness.  Aroma is a bit muted, though it opened up some as it warmed.  Taste is a nice blend of the sweet malt, fruit and hoppiness.  Palate is medium, masks the high ABV quite nicely, I would have never guessed this was 9%.
Bottle courtesy of 5000.  Pours copper with a white head.  Smells of roses, caramel, some earthy hints.  Tastes of spicy and sweet with some dark fruity hints on the finish.

had an oak aged pint from a  2004 tap nearly 5 years old, at Freds Rivertown Alehouse in Snohomish, WA.  as there isn’t a separate installment for this Im rating it here.
Balanced malts and hops, but to the sweet side.  nice oak spiciness.   I cant compare it to the non-aged version, but this is a great find.

12 ounce bottle from riversideAK. Thanks! Pours a brownish red 

color with a medium head. Sweet malty aroma some some hops, 

spice and fruity notes. Taste is dry, nutty and grainy with some 

hops in the finish. Medium bodied.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2011 12oz bottle from Yonkman65, thank you Bruce. Rating #97. Poured dark copper with a little off-white head. Sweet and a little spicy, some dark fruits. Roasty/toasty flavor, some sweet spices and a little hop bitterness, pretty good.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text:
bottle courtesy of riversideAK.

slightly hazed pale ruby brown with a creamy toasted almond colored head. some drippy lacing is present.

lots of caramel on the nose mixed with earthy warm spices, toffee, grass, red apples and faint piny leafy hops.

sugar is a non issue thanks to the ample hop content... flavors of caramel/toffee/butterscotch, toasted nuts, earthy spice/cinnamon, pine, mild bitterness and lots of dry leafy hoppiness on the finish. the hops carry through into the aftertaste where they keep parching my mouth. medium body. bitterness and hops keep it really enjoyable.
7/3.5/7.5/3/15/3.7
Bottle. Fruit and spice aroma. Tastes of spice, dark fruit, nuts, cherry and hops. Nice bitterness in the finish.
bottle from suzygreenburg.  Nutty, caramel aroma.  Butterscotch, caramel, and nuts up front with moderately bitter finish.  Good, but a little harsh.
Thanks to RiversideAK for this one!  Deep amber pour with a thin beige head and thin drippy lace. Nice malty flavor with the bitterness, being well balanced.  Warming dry finish.
Either the ABV is really high or this is really hoppy. I was suprised with the bitterness. Pours a cloudy amber and smells of spice and hops. This is a good beer but a little too alcoholic.

Bottle thanks to riversideAK.  Pours a dark amber with small brown head.  Hint of some spice and malt on the nose.  Flavor has some hop, caramilzed sugar, spice and some dried fruit.  Finish is dry with a bit of roasted malt.  Was shocked to see it was at 9%, very well hidden.

Pours dark orange with a fizzy tan head. Moderate carbonation. Aroma is of malt, chalk, chocolate, grain, spice, and mint. Taste is caramel malt up front with a heavy spiciness, balanced by a nice oat and pine taste. Lingering mint and spice taste. Very smooth, earthy flavors. Finish is very bitter.

Bottle. Pours a dark copper with almost no head. Cinnamon, moderate yeast, apple juice nose. A sweat yeast flavor with some pine resin. Some caramel too. Warm dry mouth. A bit much with the alcohol flavors. it distracts a bit. Overall a nice Christmas beer.

12 oz bottle from Bottleworks; Nose of light citrus hops, caramel, and raisins Hazy rust with a medium beige head; Flavor of light hop bitterness, caramel yeastiness, and dark fruits; finish lightly bitter.

Picked up a 12-oz bottle (2006 Vintage) from Bottleworks, north of downtown Seattle, WA. Pours a semi-cloudy (with particles)orange amber brew with a thin beige head that quickly dissipates to a fine film and no ring. Aroma of sweet caramel malt, a touch of Granny Smith apples, dark pitted fruits, and brown sugar. Taste is full bodied, very light carbonation with flavors of  grandmas mild fruit cake, dark pitted fruits, caramel malt, a touch of yeast and some brown sugar. Finish is quite sweet with a slowly disappearing dark fruit and bread aftertaste. No bitterness in this sweet winter beer.

354mL bottle poured into an English pint glass

Appearance:  Orangey-amber hue with a small white light head that quickly disappeared.  Small amount of carbonation.

Aroma:  Caramel, yeast, bread, and a hint of hops.

Taste/Palate:  Creamy on the mouth.  A nice amount of caramel, bread, and fruit is present.  A tiny hint of hops is also present.  Nice mouthfeel.  Surprisingly, the alcohol is masked quite well.

Very nice beer

bottle, from trade with 5000. Ok aroma, sweet. Caramel, paper/cardboard, little banana, apple. Little hazed brownish orange color, good head, ok lace. Bitter sweet flavor. Not an overwhelming bitterness. Little citrus bite, or maybe a sour apple, Medium body, creamy mouthfeel, bitter finish. Ok, to me, at best. Nothing to excite me about it. None of the usual christmas notes. As an english strong I guess it a tad better, but never comes together with a flavor I liked.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: 12oz bottle acquired in trade with riversideAK (thanks!). Poured a medium and lightly hazy amber color with a large sized off white head. Lots of suspended floaters. Aromas of yeast, bready, toasted malts, caramel, and all around malty. Tastes of caramel, toasty, bready, and some dark fruits. Alcohol content well hidden.

Bottled.  Poured a really cool shade of brilliant copper with a short cap of short-lived beige head.  My first impression on the aroma was green apple Jolly Ranchers (is this supposed to be "Jolly Rancher Christmas Ale"?).. caramel and dark fruity sweetness join in.. just a touch of toffee.. but then it reverts to the candy.. bizarre!  The flavor began with a sweet and sour malty impression (brown sugar, caramel, and Jolly Ranchers) followed by some rough alcohol notes over raisins and more candy.. spicy, sweet, and warm notes on the sticky finish.. Im not sure what they were shooting for, but I wasnt feeling the heavy boozy candy.  Warm and thick on the palate with sharp boozy notes especially on the back-end and finish.. this wasnt necessarily bad, but I didnt dig it.
one of my favorite beers of the season. not to dark but very bold. Lots of malty goodness. good job maritime keep it up
Ruby Amber with no head.  Aroma is toffee, caramel, nice maltiness.  Taste has an initial light hoppiness followed by almond, caramel, and a light alcohol warming.

pour is a dark copper with a small creamy light beige head, good lacing.
smell is inviting, caramel, malt, spice, brown sugar, touch of hops.
taste is a creamy, thick, full of malt, spiced rum, caramel, end is nicely bitter and a little dry.
overall a very nice brew.

I dont know if the beer got too cold or what, but when I popped the top it sounded and tasted flat. Really had very little flavor. Maybe I got a bad bottle. I would try it again based on all the other reviews, but I only had one bottle.

Pint - Eastside Club Tavern - Olympia, WA 
Aroma  Nice malty aroma with some nice bitter hops in the nose.  
Appearance  Dark golden amber color, Nice head and clear.
Flavor  Great malty slightly bitter flavor.  I liked the strong beer flavor this gave off.   
Palate  Nice Mouthfeel, good  texture with a dry finish. 
Overall  A good strong English ale flavor this was a treat for the night.

Pours a murky caramel color with a ruby hue. Couple fingers of cream colored head after an aggressive pour that died slow and leaves sticky sheets of lace. Smells of sherry, fig, plum, molassas, a little spice, very sweet. Big flavors. Sherry type alcohol is predominant with a backbone of caramel, cinnimon, fig and dried plum. Feels full in the mouth with a slightly hoppy finish. Resembles a barleywine. A sipper for sure. A nice treat but probably be even better on a snowy winter day (hence winter warmer)

Bottle. Pours ruby-tinged dark amber with a thick and lacy off-white head. Light aroma, just a bit of fruit and toffee. Medium body and moderate carbonation. The alcohol is immediately noticeable in the the taste. Hot and somewhat medicinal finish. There is some nice fruit, toffee and spice in the taste, but it gets clobbered by everything else. Im hoping for a new recipe for next year.

12oz bottle courtesy of Ibrew2or3. Thanks again, Dave. Rust colored body with a small, lasting off white head atop. When it fades spots of lacing adorn the glass. Nose of various spices, dark fruits, figs, raisins, floral spicy hops and a bit of fusel heat. Flavor contains all of the promised notes, with tons of spice and full of dark fruits and hops, along with burnt malts. Finish is lengthy, a bit of heat, then fading into raisins and plums, malts and some spice. Palate is sticky, medium bodied, very coating. Very nice.

12 oz bottle pours a clear deep amber with thin off white head. The aroma is figs and dates mixed with alcohol bringing up the rear. The taste begins both caramely sweet and dark  fruity with prunes, raisins and a bit of pepper. Then a mild mixture of caramel, roasted malts and toffee run the flavor up a notch or two. Toward the finish pine hop bitterness and a solid does of alcohol begin to bring the experience to a close. It starts very nice but ends a bit harsh.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2007 I really enjoyed this beer.  One of the better christmas beers Ive had.  Warm aroma of brown and nutmeg. dark red brown color, two finger head. Tastes warm and inviting with rich full malts and a balanced hop finish.

Cask, at the brewpub. Copper, brilliantly clear and a thin but dense beige head. Nice aroma - butterscotch, rum, caramel and toffee. Smooth palate and nicely sweet and hearty. Mollassess and dark bread, and some smoove earthy hops.

12 ounce bottle.  Shiver me timbers, but this is a good hearty holiday brew.  It pours the color of a newly minted penny, clear and sparkling, with soft carbonation.  The head is a light tan, although it mostly dissipates, leaving just a small remnant and some light lacing.

The smell is like that of a small cabin in the woods of the Pacific Northwest, stumbled upon after a walk in the rain, the fireplace heating the room and the logslight grains, caramel, light dough of baking bread, the scented woodiness of cedar.  The flavor follows suit, with a strong woody cedar flavor wrapped around a nutty, caramel base.  There is the flavor of lightly baked bread thrown in for good measure, which balances nicely against the malt and hops.

I had this with dark chocolate after dinner and the slight smoky flavor of the chocolate helped to draw out the cedar of Jolly Roger, for a great pairing of dessert and ale.  This could be a new Christmas tradition in the making.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2010 warm aroma of sugar plums and nutmeg dance through my head. dark red brown color, two finger head fell fast. tastes warm and inviting with rich full malts and a balanced hop finish. surprised there are no spices, i like that.  110510  Maybe not a sugar plum note, but definitely sweet on the nose, still get a little dusty spice.  Lots of caramel, some tobacco and maple syrup, great winter beer.   After a couple releases that I would consider off, this beer is back to its former glory status.

12 oz. bottle. A nice, well-rounded winter warmer. Not much of a head, but presents a full, spicy-sweet aroma. The flavor is full of malts, so it come across as pretty sweet, but its not overdone. If spices are added, theyre also understated--I think its just a well thought out hop profile that puts the tang on the tongue. Have tried this beer in the past, and have not been knocked over by it, but this years batch seems mighty tasty. Ill buy it again before the seasons over.

Good - could be great. Very rich, strong caramelly malt base. Toffee with hits of raisins and lots, I repeat, LOTS of spices (not heavy, just lots of them). Strong atgringent hop bitterness with a resiny finish. What really keeps this from reaching that next level is the slight metallic essence which is accentuated by the spiciness of the drink. 9% is not overpowering but you definetly notice its presence. Really good regardless.

Requires a vigorous pour to create a reasonable head, which dies down quickly. This is no foamer. Lovely red-golden coloration, tart on the tongue, not over spiced like so many Christmas Ales Ive had to suffer through. One could quite easily go through a six-pack of these without getting overwhelmed by excessive spicing. Fantastic packaging, to boot.

On Tap (nitro,cask, co2) and bottles. Used to go to the brewery and buy 22ozers. Have spent many nights on 12/24 wrapping presents while downing Jolly Roger. My wife and I refer to Jolly Roger as the "Big Naughty". This is a big, deep dark malty monster on steroids. Never too sweet, always balanced. Be sure you are at home, sit back, relax and "enter the room" of Jolly Roger. You wont be disappointed.

Tasted 9/22/07.  12oz bottle.  Murky with an amber brown hue.  Vigorous off-white head.  Sweet malty aromas.  Soggy cereal malts.  Apples straw and bread.  Cold weather aromas personified.  Full bodied and cidery sweet.  Nice with a persistant burn.  Big malts with flavors of cocoa and tea.  Mulling spices.  Super watery coffee acidity.  Citrus and pine hop notes.  Brewed without spices or other ingredients?  Still delicious.  This is a fun beer!  Respect to the brewer!

Date: 10/26/1997
Mode: Bottle
Source: Burlingame Grocery, OR

dark amber, frothy tan head, strong spicy malt aroma, rich malt flavor, hint of spices, slight bitterness in the finish

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.2/5.0Score: **+/4
-------- />
The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
12 oz Bottle Pours out a dark amber topped with a light tan head. Nice malt aroma. Tast of 9% NO WAY alcohol very well covered up.

Dark, dark amber color.  Aroma is malty and spicy.  Flavor is strong, and the alcohol is immediately noticeable.  Reminds me of an English barley wine.   Some good toffee and malt flavors present.  Pretty good.

Very smooth for the alcohol content though it possesses a nose of alcohol.  Sweet, malty and quite quaffable.  A true pleasure was this beer.  Somewhat spicy.  Dark with a coruscating creamy head.  Notes of caramel and toffee were evident.  Yum!
VERY malty. Sweet. Dark amber. Tasty. Pretty good stuff. Love this brewpub.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2007 Nice malty aroma with some hints of toffee. A darker reddish hue with a smaller creamy head. This was a fantastically complex beer with flavors of toffee, sweet dates, and a little vanilla?. Not overly sweet. No noticable sourness as the rater below me points out. Some more noticable alcohol as it warms up, but for being 9 %, this is extremely quaffable, so be carfeful because "Itll Get You Drunk"!
overly done and complicated.  It tastes like sweet flavors were added to cover up the sour finish.  Typical of bad beers with high alcohol content

Thanks to my SS. 12 oz bottle poured a hazy amber redish gold, Small off white creamy head. Nose was spicey and real sweet., caramel and trace alcohol. The lacing was very good.  Taste was sweet and strong. Gooey caramel toffee and spices, like a slight cinamin and holiday cookie yeast taste. No nasty after taste for me. Felt the alcohol warming, but did not really notice it in the taste. Nice holiday cheer from this beer.

12-oz. Pours a hazy, creamy-looking darkish amber with coppery highlights. Thick, sticky-looking, lacy off-white film across the top. Intensely sweet and gooey-smelling caramel and butterscotch on the nose. Put it all together and what do you have? A grain bill monstrosity for sure. Semi-bold attack; medium body, palpable carb, rather assertive flavors. The mid-palate comes through on the promise of crackers, bread, caramel, and butterscotch that the nose makes, and goes it one better with some old leaves and smoky acridity. The hops really buckle down and cut through the goop with some bittering. Alcohols well-hidden. This is a mean little take-no-prisoners Christmas beer, and the ads for this one have historically been the coolest beer ads Ive seen in print.
(Bottle) Shared at the PNW Christmas 2006 party at Oakes on December 9th. Thin, lasting almond head with a copper body. Nose is highly malted with an iodine tinge. Strong malt with a tinniness.
Mahogany with small spots of lace. Nutmeg or ginger nose. Caramel malts and bitter hops. Bitter flavor with a lot of spice. Makes your tongue feel a bit fuuzy. Spice finish.

Cloudy light amber body with little off white head.  Aroma is fruity with lemon and peach.  Nice hops throughout this well balanceed ship.  Effective but not overwhelming.  Good beer but doesnt really do anything special.
Aroma of malt and a bit of hop. Apricot amber color with little head. Starts with malt, stays that way for a bit, then some hop arrives. Then the malt returns to balance the hop. Unusual.

12oz bottle via trade with indiana_red - thanks ken! - Pours dark copper with a short tan head that leaves some lace.  Aromas of fresh caramel malts and some PNW hops.  Flavor is caramel, raisin, some good fruity notes, and slight bitterness on the finish.  Good medium body with a crisp finish.  Alcohol is well hidden.. Not bad..

Sadly, this local (Seattle) beer didnt finish highly in the Winter beer ratings my friends and I conducted. The metallic finish was the biggest problem. It starts off promisingly with a slightly sweet maltiness which gives way to a bit of hop bitterness. The aftertaste was a real turnoff though.

Not much aroma, but what is there is nice. Nice ruby tinted brown color with smallish pale tan head disipating to very thin hints quickly. Not overly sweet for the style and has a decent bitter middle that almost tastes burned. Nothing special in the aftertaste. Overall, nothing particularly bad about this beer and it does seem to hide the 9% pretty well. Definitely a decent seasonal.

Bottle. Pours a reddish amber color with a off-white head on top. Aroma is malty with fruit, caramel, and spices. Flavor is caramel, fruit, malts, spice, with a touch of hops. Definitely a sipping beer, a bit heavy and syrupy. A decent seasonal ale.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2009 On tap at the brewery. Had this one last and after a sub-par rest of the gauntlet at MP was pleasantly surprised. Whiskey coloured. Sweet, roasted malts and holiday-like spices. Lasting, sweet, smoked finish. Alcohol extremely noticeable on finish. Highly recommended and will get more next time Im out.

(12 oz bottle: Obtained 30-Nov-05 in trade with Larry Pitonka, thanks André!) Yo-Ho-Ho-ly Cow, this beer is terrific!  Right off the bat, the fruity, malty, sweet, caramel candy nose is amazing.  The candy-like, caramely maltiness carries through even more in the flavor.  Sugary and sweet (but in a quality way), a hint of butter, but balanced by a fair amount of bitter hops.  Im thinking this has a flavor profile similar to a British-style American barleywine without quite the same heaviness.  Definitely a full-bodied beer, even pushing close to the realm of syrupy.  I suppose this would seem cloying to many people, but I like dessert-like beers and wines, so Im fine with this.  Carbonation is mild.  The amber body seems hazy, but upon closer inspection, its haziness is from the small particles suspended in the beer.  Otherwise, the beer seems quite clear actually.  The small, off-white head settles to a thin ring, but not before depositing some patchy lacing near the the top of the glass.  A very solid offering that I wasnt expecting to like this much.  Will definitely have to seek out this brewery the next time Im in Seattle.

Cask version, marks as above  Mahogany-chestnut, clear; rather good head. Slightly fishy ( adequate, maybe?) & hoppy nose, but no C-hops onslaught. And then theres both vanilla and diacetyl underneath. Sweet, butterscotch, toffee and a hop onslaught sticking uneasily on it. This is totally unbalanced and actually off-putting. Sticky, not to say cloying and very badly... "casked"??? A very poor show. They seem not to know how to handle this.

 Bottled, slightly aged, thanks to DonGS  Hazy red-foxy; rosy-amber head, small but dense, leaving some good rings.  4  Some malts in a cookie way; hops abundant all the same, and a pretty vinous character.  7  Definitely some oxydation, licorice, fruity taste - raspberry pour.  6  Despite its ABV, and malt toll, its a bit watery - the oxydation?  3  Good, but it suffered from its - relatively short - aging.  14 =  3.4

This is a yummy little rendition of this style.  I love it when these are transformed into holiday ales.  Big juicy fruit aromas, with a bit of alcohol behind them, with lots of rich carmalized brown sugar.  Has a sweet maltiness, but not over the top, richly overbalanced and a little spicy, but a very solid and delicious ale.
Slightly hazy amber colour.  Interesting sweet caramel aroma with lots of brown sugar, and light fruits.  Quite malty, almost candyish.  Decent beer, though a bit too sweet for my tastes.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2006 Draught at the Brouwers Cafe, Seattle.  Clear dark amber. Appley nose. Very sweet, thick and syrupy. Plenty of malt, but everything gets lost in a sea of syrup. A dentists wet dream.

Deep reddish orange color, semi-smeared, thin ivory topping; keeps a good skim and collar present throughout the session. Stringy rings of lace coat the glass.

Aroma is juicy with berries, jam, and caramel with a touch of Ameretto.

Taste plays out with what the aroma gives out, and quite nicely too. Fruity and jelly-like with some purple grape, apple, cherry, and berries, all mingling within a marmalade-like threshold and caramel smoothness. Sliding warm finishing quality with the caramel and floral hop notes.

Semi-sticky and cloying with malty sweet action and silky smoothness. Body is mediumish with a light carbonation that tends to build slightly into the finish. Nice little warming hints gradually gain hold as you go. A nice beer; perfect for helping warm up the winter.

Cherries, plums, raisins, apples and bananas are apparent in the ashy yet sweet aroma.  Clear ruby brown body is topped by a decent, fine bubbled, tan head that recedes to cover.  Marzipan like nuttiness and a light chocolatey note underlie the thick beryy, plum and cherry fruitiness.  Malty sweetness is cut by a moderate bitterness before returning with some light spices in the aftertaste.  Medium body with fair carbonation and a very smooth texture.  Tulip glass.  Allowed to warm from fridge temperature.  Bottle (trade, May-05).  Thanks, jahnoth!
Pretty darn good. Solid body, tastes like Christmas. Whatever herbs or spices they added do enhance the hoppiness and its all rounded well out by solid malt.

Poured an almost clear almost ruby color with a medium off-white head.  Thick apearance the way the bubbles slowly rise to form the head.  Sweet fruity aroma with cherries and plum.  A little bit of bubble gum.  Aroma is thick.  Malty flavor lightly fruity but not distinct in any one flavor.  Moderate bitterness starts mid way and has nice length.  Medium to full body and almost sillky.  Never heard of this beer before so it was a pleasant surprise after trying it.
Ruby color.  Not much aroma; basic amber aromas.  Crisp carbonation in the mouth.  Flavor is balanced, drinkable, unremarkable.

Bottle from LarryPitonka.  Crystal clear, beautiful ruby color with a rather dense tan head which fades to nothingness.  Decent lacing is left initially.  Slight plummy/figgy aroma, some caramel sweetness and a hint of booze.  Medium bodied with a slightly lower carbonation level.  Sweet flavored with a more than adequate dose of hop bitterness.  Light spices and alcohol.  Decently done.

12 oz bottle.  Deep ruby-brown beer with a thick light tan head.  Sweet malty and spicy aroma, nutmeg, cinnamon.  A bit of plummy aroma as well.  Smells like a gingerbread cookie.  Flavour is spicy over sweet caramel and toffee malts.  A bit of diacetyl flavour, but isnt objectionable.  Sticky, puddingy malts with a clove-dominated spicy flavour.  Lingering bready malt finish.  As it warms, the peppery alcohol and spicy hops really come forward.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2007 From the bottle

Pours a deep copper with a decent head. Aroma is a nice balance of warm malt, hops, and spice, but the flavor is decidedly sweet for my palate. The spice and roasted malts clash with a dose of hops that, in more modest company, would themselves pack a considerable blast. The mouthfeel is oily, sticky, and other than its density it hides its 9% very well. Not bad, but not a standout. 7/4/6/3/14=3.4

2006 version, draft
This is a big oily alcoholic mess of a winter beer. I dont see the point. 6/3/5/3/10=2.7. Ill average it out to 3.1.
Brilliant bright red appearance. Strong malty dark fruit (prune) aroma and notable spice. Well spiced bready malt palate, caramel, toffee and dark fruits. Fair bitterness in the finish.

This beer pours a cloudy copper color with a soapy white head and little bit of lacing on the sides of the glass. The aroma is full of whiskey, malt, cloves, earthiness, wood, bourbon and super sappiness. The flavor is much like a combination of sweetened wood and coca cola with undertones of cloves and cinnamon. After it warms a bit the vanilla in the finish also becomes a tad more pronounced. Mild levels of carbonation, somewhat prickling when cold and tongue coating in texture. Perhaps a touch of grainy roasted barley as well...strange.

Bottle: From reading some of the other ratings, I think I tasted a spoiled bottle.  It smelled right, but didnt taste right.  But as far as appearance it had a lovely burnt siena color with average density along with a hazy look.  I did pick up on hints of vanilla, cola and caramel.
Tap. Very dark amber. Light ring of foam around the glass. Very good light spice and alcohol aroma. Throat burning spice in the finish. Moderate flavour and noticeable alcohol.

Deep red body, thin light cream head.  Big toffee aroma with raisins, caramel, and a touch of prune.  Yeah, its like a holiday dessert.  The flavor isnt as interesting, but its still pretty nice with toast and a touch of toffee and dark fruits, notes of caramel, and hints of red grapes in the finish as well as bread.  Nice balance of toasty and sweet flavors.  There may be a touch of spicing too (cinnamon?).  Thanks Dan (jah noth) for the bottle!
on tap at the jolly roger in seattle. dark purple colour. pleasant bread and butter pudding and raisin flavours with some decent dryness. quite warming, good stuff

Bottle Pours a nice rich clear mahogany, with very little head and just enough off white ring to maintain fine lacing.  A good malty aroma includes apples, cinamon, caramel.  Slight alcohol as well.  A woody, malty flavor that hides the ABV quite well.  Flavors are fairly subtle, nothing really reaches out and grabs ya.  Mild, easy, and soft.  Not much carbonation, and a slightly chalky feel at teh end.  Easy on the hops and not much bitter on the aftertaste.  Nice seasonal from the PNW.  Thanks to a non-RB friend for this reccomendation.

Rich malty aroma.  Slight head on the pour that disappears.  Beautiful crimson in color.  Sweet cherry malt flavor with a twinge of alcohol.  I taste a swirl of malts, but not the typical adjuncts of a Christmas ale.  Nice brew, but watch out.

Brazen crimson color, nearly bronze, slight haze, with a thin coating of beige foam above. 
Lovely aromatics, dark fruits, cherries, sherry, a bit of plums and port, hoppy, rich and warm. Very inviting, and I cant wait to taste her! (him?)
Snappy, brisk, fully flavorful entry on the palate, comes crashing in the door loaded with flavor, abundantly hoppy, juicy, spicy flavors...spiced with what, exactly, I dont know. Junipers? Cloves? Cinnamon?
Big, fresh, sparkling flavor, fruity, dynamic, ...sings with the sort of zest I enjoy in many a delicious Belgian ale. Bright, vibrant, and very tasty. Yum, yum, yum, I say it three times, so it must be true
This is a winter brew with real cohones!

Bottle pours ruby, large frothy off-white colored head, fine lacing, with soft carbonation. &nbsp Sweet biscuity aroma, malts, with slightly fruity hop flair. &nbsp Malty, semi-sweet, with a somewhat syrupy butterscotch/caramel flavor (much like a doppelbock). &nbsp Good body, medium mouthfeel. &nbsp The 9% ABV is certainly there, but quite smooth. &nbsp Light finish, slightly warming, semi-sweet, candyish, malty, with a very minor hop note. &nbsp Much smoother and lighter (for the same ABV) as compared to earlier years. &nbsp A PNW Favorite!

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2006 Draft. Dark ruby color with a small white head. Spice and malt aroma. An almost creamy mouthfeel. Xmas spices with some opange peel and sweet malt/toffee flavors. Theres a spicey hop underlying everything, but its just a tad too sweet with the malt

Ruby bronze, light head & lacing. The aroma is sweet with some alcohol, maple, Muscat grapes, French toast. Complex! The flavor is up front with sweet grapes & licorice. Finishes medium bodied and with more alcohol feel.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Jolly Roger. Pretty malty. Lots of nutty, toffee, raisiny sort of flavour, a bit spicey. Good off-dry hoppy finish, fairly assertive, not too bad.
Spicy as hell. Decent body. Some sweet caramel notes, but a domination by ethanol. This may put you off, but this beer is dangerous. A very appropriate winter beer, I'm going to go pound this.
On draft.  Pours dark brown color, aroma of malt and alcohol generally.  Nice smooth, holiday warmer taste with good balance of malt and hops and good alcohol flavor for those cold nights.

2003 12 oz. bottle. Pours a deep, dark brownish amber with a decent tan creamy head. Rich, complex nose. Fruity, sweet, light spice. Definitely dry-hopped very well. Taste matches the nose to a tee. Very similar to 90 Min IPA by Dogfishead but with more caramel. A slight toastiness can also be found. I think there may even be just a touch of chocolate malt. Little lingering bitterness. Exceptionally smooth. One one the more superior winter brews out there.
this is such bad beer the label on it says it all you will look like the dead after drinking this stuff.flavor of this reminds me of eggnog with brandy.YUCK
Thanks to Gregory for this bottle. Nice solid winter beer, even for late March. Nice good mix of spice, malt, hops.

Brilliant red-amber body with a crisp head that fades. Cotton candy aroma with an intense bubble gum quality and gorgeous malt touch--one of the vey best english strong ale bouquets.  The flavor is of refined candy malt and alcohol--transfixed so it does not waver--extremely consistent throughout and well balanced with a PNW hop tone.  A great english strong ale.
Now this is what winter brews are all about.  Deliciously sweet with a well hoped background.  Spicey and complex, something new throughout the whole six pack.  Could pass for a barley wine.

This is what Christmas is about. Thanks to beer like this and LaConners Tennenbaum I can feel assured that Christmas is yet again serving a purpose: making me happy. Okay, so this may be selfish, but Im a narrow-minded bastard. I love the complexity here: sweet caramels, nutmeg or a similar spice, and a nice hoppy tang to keep the malt in check.
Wonderful Holiday ale. Deep brown color on the pour, aroma is light and sweet.  The flavor is rich, malty with some caramel touches.  Full Flavored, full bodied.  Really awesome brew.

ReRate 12/17/2002 - Just had this at the brewery on nitro. The N really brought out the malt aromas, even though they serve it way too cold. There seemed to be a hint of holiday spice as well, could be my ass talking. Sweetness was also quite enhanced at the brewery. Really damn sweet. Ill knock it up a couple on the flavor and overall.           11/4/2002 -Dark amber color with a thin head. Serious caramel and molasses aroma with a hint of hop spiciness. Sweet start of coarse - spicey (hops) middle - and a bitter finish. Slight grassy aftertaste. Good winter brew from my neighborhood. Arrrh.
Despite popular belief this isnt the same every year, but is traditionally good since 93

Dark amber color, medium head. Rich roasted malts, slightly hoppy. Rich and full bodied. Smooth taste. Nice flavor. Good hop/malt balance. Mouthfeel is round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is malty, slightly bitter

seriously thick and heavy.  light to moderately hopped.  very, very strong.  dark and roasted, but the predominant flavor is malty-sweetness. nice deep-red color.  a must for winter-beer / strong ale fans.  very nice.

Intense flavor, this dark amber holiday ale, sweet spicy flavors, of carmel malts and bitter/spicey hops mingle in your mouth, alcohol more around 9.5% and more depending on year, this beer warms you up, perfect for nw winter drinking, go to the tap room to try iy on nitro, amazing!
orangey, light golden color.  Vegetal - potato?, sweet caramel, sugary aroma.  Soft mouthfeel.  Sweet malty body, nice hop bite in the palate.

Semi hazy light copper. Suspended particles. Thin edge head. Trace carbonation. Aroma of fruit and caramel. Medium thick body loaded with strawberries, spicy alcohol and a mellow herbiness. Solid English Style Strong Ale. Earthy/floral hop balance with a savory aftertaste. Caramel malts, some roastedness. Not cloying. Lasting bitterness and a caramel/fruit finish. A nice sipper. Thanks to my pal Gusler.

This beer reminds me of the Pyramid Snow cap because of all the strange flavors that come up intermitently.  There is a very sweet, yet sour contrast, and a candy-spice flavor that is VERY strong!  As I understand it, the brew for 2001 was closer to 9.5% alcohol, and so it almost borders on a barley wine!  The color is not particularly representative of how truly special the taste is.  Many of the Maritime Brewing company beers seem to leave me with a feeling that I had a very unique beer, but not something I would nessasarily try again.  This one I WILL look for next year, though!

Deep dark brown and some what hazy colr, brown head and decent lace that dissipates quickly. Nose is malt and the aroma of the Cascade and Chinook hops are also present. Front is malt sweet, the middle moderate as is the carbonation. The finish is hop spicy, dry, with a high abv, this is quite a treat.

This beer is by far my favorite winter seasonal ale.  Not only does it have a wonderful hearty rich taste but high alcohol content.  The two make a deadly combination in a wet place like Seattle.  Drink a few of these and it doesnt feel as cold outside anymore.  Rich color and full aroma make this a Seattle favorite.  The Maritime Pacific Brewing company even has a taproom named after this very famous winter classic.  Maritime once again has outdone themselves with a high quality great tasting beer.  I only wish it was carried in more local stores.
Deep garnet color; thin but lively head; candy sugar and cinnamon in the nose. Heavy whiskey flavors upfront to start the pint. Very warming. Warms to a ton of sweetness. No subtlety here.
